questions.question: Under ASC 321, equity investments without readily determinable fair values may be measured using:

options.B: Lower of cost or market
options.C: Fair value through net income or the measurement alternative

questions.explanation: Equity securities are measured at FV-NI by default. For those without readily determinable fair values, entities can elect the measurement alternative (cost minus impairment, adjusted for observable price changes).
questions.tip: Equity: FV-NI default; measurement alternative for no-FV securities.

questions.question: On Jan 1, a company purchases stock for $50,000. On Dec 31, fair value is $58,000. Under FV-NI, what is recognized in net income?

options.B: $8,000 unrealized gain
options.C: $8,000 in OCI

questions.explanation: Equity investments are measured at FV with changes in fair value recognized in net income (FV-NI). Unrealized gain = $58,000 - $50,000 = $8,000.
questions.tip: Equity securities: FV changes go to net income, not OCI.

questions.question: Held-to-maturity debt securities are measured at:

options.A: Fair value with changes in net income
options.B: Fair value with changes in OCI
options.C: Amortized cost

questions.explanation: HTM securities are measured at amortized cost (purchase price adjusted for premium/discount amortization). Fair value changes are not recognized.
questions.tip: HTM = amortized cost; AFS = FV through OCI; Trading = FV through NI.

questions.question: AFS bonds purchased for $100,000 have a year-end fair value of $106,000 and amortized cost of $101,000. What is reported in OCI?

options.B: $6,000 unrealized gain
options.C: $7,000 unrealized gain

questions.explanation: AFS unrealized G/L = FV - Amortized cost = $106,000 - $101,000 = $5,000 gain reported in OCI.
questions.tip: AFS: unrealized = FV - amortized cost (not original cost).

questions.question: Trading debt securities are reported at fair value with unrealized gains and losses recognized in:

options.B: Net income
options.C: Retained earnings

questions.explanation: Trading securities are measured at fair value with all changes (unrealized gains and losses) recognized in net income.
questions.tip: Trading = FV through net income (like equity securities).

questions.question: When AFS debt securities are reclassified to trading, the unrealized gain or loss previously in AOCI is:

options.B: Reclassified to net income immediately
options.C: Amortized over the remaining life

questions.explanation: When reclassifying from AFS to trading, the cumulative unrealized gain or loss in AOCI is immediately recognized in net income.
questions.tip: AFS to trading: flush AOCI to income.

questions.question: Under ASC 326 (CECL), credit losses on AFS debt securities are:

options.A: Written off immediately against the security
options.B: Recorded as an allowance, limited to the amount FV is below amortized cost
options.C: Ignored until securities are sold

questions.explanation: For AFS securities, credit losses are recorded through an allowance (not a direct writedown). The allowance is limited to the difference between FV and amortized cost.
questions.tip: AFS credit loss: allowance method; capped at FV below amortized cost.

questions.question: Credit losses on HTM debt securities under CECL are recognized:

options.A: Only when the security is sold
options.B: At purchase, with ongoing adjustments, based on expected lifetime credit losses
options.C: Only when the issuer files for bankruptcy

questions.explanation: Under CECL, HTM securities require an allowance for expected credit losses from the date of acquisition, updated each period for changes in expectations.
questions.tip: CECL for HTM: recognize expected lifetime losses upfront, adjust as needed.

questions.question: The equity method is generally used when an investor owns:

options.B: 20-50% of the investee (significant influence)
options.C: More than 50% of the investee

questions.explanation: Equity method is used when the investor has significant influence, typically presumed at 20-50% ownership. Over 50% generally requires consolidation.
questions.tip: 20-50% = equity method (significant influence); >50% = consolidation.

questions.question: An investor owns 30% of an investee. The investee reports net income of $500,000 and pays dividends of $100,000. What does the investor record as investment income?
questions.explanation: Equity method income = Ownership % × Investee net income = 30% × $500,000 = $150,000. Dividends reduce the investment, not income.
questions.tip: Equity method: income = share of earnings; dividends reduce investment.

questions.question: Using the previous example (30% ownership, $500,000 income, $100,000 dividends), what is the effect of dividends on the investment account?

options.B: Decrease of $30,000
options.C: No effect

questions.explanation: Dividends received reduce the investment account under equity method: 30% × $100,000 = $30,000 decrease. Dividends are not income; they're a return of investment.
questions.tip: Equity method dividends: Dr. Cash, Cr. Investment.

questions.question: An investor pays $2,000,000 for 25% of an investee (book value $6,000,000). The $500,000 excess is attributable to equipment with 10 years remaining life. Annual amortization adjustment is:

options.B: $50,000 increase to equity income
options.C: $500,000 decrease to equity income

questions.explanation: Excess paid over book value ($2M - 25% × $6M = $500,000) allocated to equipment is amortized over 10 years: $500,000 ÷ 10 = $50,000/year reduction to equity income.
questions.tip: Equity method: amortize excess FV over asset lives (reduces income).

questions.question: An investor (30% ownership) sells inventory to the investee at a profit. Under the equity method:

options.B: The investor eliminates its share (30%) of the unrealized profit
options.C: The investor eliminates 100% of the profit

questions.explanation: Under equity method, intercompany profits are eliminated to the extent of the investor's ownership. For downstream sales, eliminate investor's share of unrealized profit.
questions.tip: Equity method intercompany profit: eliminate investor's share.

questions.question: An investor can elect the fair value option for an equity method investment. If elected:

options.A: Changes in fair value are recorded in OCI
options.B: Changes in fair value are recorded in net income, and equity method is not applied
options.C: The investment is recorded at cost
options.D: The election can be revoked at any time

questions.explanation: The fair value option can be elected at acquisition for equity method investments. If elected, the investment is carried at FV with changes in net income. The election is irrevocable.
questions.tip: FVO for equity method: FV through NI instead of equity accounting.

questions.question: When equity method losses reduce the investment account to zero:

options.A: Additional losses continue to reduce the investment below zero
options.B: The investor discontinues recognizing losses unless it has guaranteed obligations or is otherwise committed
options.C: The investment is written off and never reinstated
options.D: The investor switches to the cost method

questions.explanation: When the investment reaches zero, loss recognition stops unless the investor has guaranteed obligations of the investee or is otherwise committed to provide further support.
questions.tip: Equity losses: stop at zero unless further commitments exist.

questions.question: If an entity transfers a debt security from HTM to AFS, the security is:

options.A: Transferred at amortized cost with no gain or loss
options.B: Transferred at fair value with any unrealized gain or loss recognized in net income
options.C: Transferred at fair value with any unrealized gain or loss recognized in OCI

questions.explanation: HTM to AFS transfer: security is remeasured to fair value with the unrealized gain or loss recorded in OCI (consistent with AFS treatment).
questions.tip: HTM to AFS: unrealized G/L goes to OCI.

questions.question: AFS securities (cost $80,000, FV $95,000, AOCI unrealized gain $15,000) are sold for $95,000. What realized gain is reported in net income?
questions.explanation: On sale, the $15,000 unrealized gain is reclassified from OCI to net income as a realized gain. Total gain = Proceeds - Original cost = $95,000 - $80,000 = $15,000.
questions.tip: AFS sale: reclassify AOCI to realized gain in income.

questions.question: An AFS bond purchased at $96,000 has face value of $100,000, stated rate 5%, and effective rate 6%. What is Year 1 interest income?
questions.explanation: Interest income = Amortized cost × Effective rate = $96,000 × 6% = $5,760.
questions.tip: Interest income = carrying value × effective rate (market rate at purchase).

questions.question: An investor must consolidate an investee when it has:

options.B: Ownership over 20%
options.C: A controlling financial interest (typically over 50% voting power)

questions.explanation: Consolidation is required when the investor has a controlling financial interest, generally indicated by ownership of more than 50% of voting shares.
questions.tip: >50% voting = consolidation; 20-50% = equity method.

questions.question: A variable interest entity must be consolidated by:

options.B: The primary beneficiary (power to direct activities + majority of economic benefits/losses)
options.C: The entity that created the VIE

questions.explanation: A VIE is consolidated by its primary beneficiary—the party that has both (1) the power to direct activities that most significantly impact economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses or receive benefits that could be significant.
questions.tip: VIE: consolidated by primary beneficiary (power + economics).

questions.question: An investment in a corporate joint venture is typically accounted for using:

options.B: Proportionate consolidation
options.C: The equity method

questions.explanation: Under US GAAP, corporate joint ventures are typically accounted for using the equity method. Proportionate consolidation is not permitted under US GAAP.
questions.tip: US GAAP: JVs use equity method; no proportionate consolidation.

questions.question: Under the measurement alternative for equity without readily determinable FV, the investment is adjusted when:

options.A: The investor believes value has changed
options.B: There's an observable transaction for identical or similar securities of the same issuer
options.C: Annual impairment testing indicates a change

questions.explanation: Under the measurement alternative, the investment is adjusted when there's an observable price change from an orderly transaction for identical or similar securities of the same issuer.
questions.tip: Measurement alternative: adjust for observable price changes only.

questions.question: Under the measurement alternative, impairment exists when:

options.B: The impairment is other-than-temporary
options.C: Qualitative assessment indicates carrying value exceeds fair value
options.D: A 20% decline in value has occurred

questions.explanation: Under the measurement alternative, a qualitative assessment determines if impairment exists. If it's more likely than not that FV < CV, the entity estimates FV and records impairment.
questions.tip: Measurement alternative impairment: qualitative assessment first.

questions.question: For equity investments at FV-NI, dividends received are recorded as:

options.A: A reduction in the investment account
options.B: Dividend income
options.C: Part of unrealized gains

questions.explanation: Dividends from equity investments at FV-NI are recorded as dividend income when declared/received. They do not reduce the investment (unlike equity method).
questions.tip: FV-NI dividends = income; Equity method dividends = reduce investment.

questions.question: Equity securities that management intends to sell within the next year should be classified as:

options.B: Noncurrent assets
options.C: Either current or noncurrent at management's discretion
options.D: Trading securities are always current; others are noncurrent

questions.explanation: Securities intended to be sold within one year are classified as current assets. Intent drives classification for equity securities.
questions.tip: Intent to sell within 1 year = current asset.

questions.question: If an entity sells HTM securities for reasons other than those permitted (e.g., credit deterioration, change in tax law), the consequence is:

options.B: The HTM portfolio may be 'tainted,' requiring reclassification of remaining HTM securities
options.C: Only the sold securities are affected
options.D: The entity must restate prior periods

questions.explanation: Selling HTM securities for inappropriate reasons calls into question the entity's intent to hold others to maturity, potentially requiring reclassification of the entire HTM portfolio (tainting).
questions.tip: HTM sales for wrong reasons = potential tainting of HTM portfolio.

questions.question: A company purchases $100,000 face value bonds at par plus two months of accrued interest (6% annual). What is the total cash paid?
questions.tip: Accrued interest at purchase is recorded as receivable, not cost.

questions.question: When ownership drops below 20% and significant influence is lost, the equity method investment is:

options.A: Continued at book value with no further adjustments
options.B: Remeasured to fair value with any gain or loss recognized in net income
options.C: Written down to zero

questions.explanation: When the equity method is discontinued, the retained investment is remeasured to fair value. The difference between FV and carrying value is recognized in net income.
questions.tip: Losing equity method: remeasure to FV, recognize G/L in income.

questions.question: When an equity method investee reports OCI items (e.g., unrealized gains on AFS securities), the investor:

options.B: Records its share of the investee's OCI in its own OCI
options.C: Records its share in net income

questions.explanation: Under the equity method, the investor recognizes its proportionate share of the investee's OCI in its own OCI, maintaining consistency.
questions.tip: Equity method: share of investee OCI goes to investor's OCI.

questions.question: An embedded derivative must be bifurcated (separated) from the host contract when:

options.A: The embedded derivative has any value
options.B: The combined instrument is not measured at FV-NI and the embedded derivative is not clearly and closely related to the host
options.C: The host is a debt instrument
options.D: The contract is with a related party

questions.explanation: Bifurcation is required when: (1) the combined instrument is not at FV-NI, (2) the embedded derivative would be a derivative if freestanding, and (3) the economic characteristics are not clearly and closely related to the host.
questions.tip: Bifurcate if: not FV-NI + not clearly related to host.

questions.question: The cost method for investments is generally used for:

options.B: Investments in equity without readily determinable FV that elect the measurement alternative
options.C: All debt securities

questions.explanation: The measurement alternative (cost minus impairment, adjusted for observable prices) is essentially a modified cost method for equity investments without readily determinable fair value.
questions.tip: Cost-based = measurement alternative for no-FV equity securities.

questions.question: AFS debt security unrealized gains and losses are reported in:

options.B: Other comprehensive income, included in total comprehensive income
options.C: Only disclosed in notes

questions.explanation: AFS unrealized gains and losses are reported in OCI and are included in total comprehensive income (net income + OCI).
questions.tip: AFS unrealized = OCI; flows through comprehensive income.

questions.question: Trading securities purchased for $25,000 with year-end FV of $28,000 are sold the following year for $30,000. What realized gain is recognized in Year 2?
questions.explanation: Year 2 gain = Sale price - Carrying value at beginning of Year 2 = $30,000 - $28,000 = $2,000. The $3,000 gain was already recognized in Year 1.
questions.tip: Trading sale gain = proceeds - FV at prior period end.

questions.question: Required disclosures for debt securities include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Amortized cost and fair value by major security type
options.B: Contractual maturities
options.C: Names of all issuers

questions.explanation: Disclosures include aggregate FV, amortized cost, unrealized gains/losses, and maturities. Individual issuer names are not required unless there are significant concentrations.
questions.tip: Investment disclosures: aggregate info, not individual issuer names.

questions.question: When an investee declares a 2-for-1 stock split, the investor holding 1,000 shares:

options.A: Records income equal to the value of new shares
options.B: Increases the investment account by the FV of new shares
options.C: Adjusts the number of shares held but not the total cost basis
options.D: Records a reduction in the investment

questions.explanation: Stock splits and stock dividends increase the number of shares held but do not change the total cost basis. The per-share cost is adjusted proportionately.
questions.tip: Stock split: more shares, same total cost basis.
